trans-unit.source: Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Common Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns
trans-unit.target: Common Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns

trans-unit.source: Common Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns
trans-unit.target: Common Azure Stream Analytics Query Patterns

trans-unit.source: Queries in Azure Stream Analytics are expressed in a SQL-like query language, which is documented <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Queries in Azure Stream Analytics are expressed in a SQL-like query language, which is documented <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This document outlines solutions to several common query patterns based on real world scenarios.
trans-unit.target: This document outlines solutions to several common query patterns based on real world scenarios.

trans-unit.source: It is a work in progress and will continue to be updated with new patterns on an ongoing basis.
trans-unit.target: It is a work in progress and will continue to be updated with new patterns on an ongoing basis.

trans-unit.source: Description: Define the types of the properties on the input stream.
trans-unit.target: Description: Define the types of the properties on the input stream.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Car weight is coming on the input stream as strings and needs to be converted to INT to perform SUM it up.
trans-unit.target: e.g. Car weight is coming on the input stream as strings and needs to be converted to INT to perform SUM it up.

trans-unit.source: Use a CAST statement on the Weight field to specify its type (see the list of supported Data Types <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Use a CAST statement on the Weight field to specify its type (see the list of supported Data Types <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Using Like/Not like to do pattern matching
trans-unit.target: Using Like/Not like to do pattern matching

trans-unit.source: Description: Check that a field value on the event matches a certain pattern
trans-unit.target: Description: Check that a field value on the event matches a certain pattern

trans-unit.source: e.g. Return license plates that start with A and end with 9
trans-unit.target: e.g. Return license plates that start with A and end with 9

trans-unit.source: Use the LIKE statement to check that the LicensePlate field value starts with A then has any string of zero or more characters and it ends with 9.
trans-unit.target: Use the LIKE statement to check that the LicensePlate field value starts with A then has any string of zero or more characters and it ends with 9.

trans-unit.source: Specify logic for different cases/values (CASE statements)
trans-unit.target: Specify logic for different cases/values (CASE statements)

trans-unit.source: Description: Provide different computation for a field based on some criteria.
trans-unit.target: Description: Provide different computation for a field based on some criteria.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Provide a string description for how many cars passed of the same make with a special case for 1.
trans-unit.target: e.g. Provide a string description for how many cars passed of the same make with a special case for 1.

trans-unit.source: The CASE clause allows us to provide a different computation based on some criteria (in our case the count of cars in the aggregate window).
trans-unit.target: The CASE clause allows us to provide a different computation based on some criteria (in our case the count of cars in the aggregate window).

trans-unit.source: Description: Send data to multiple output targets from a single job.
trans-unit.target: Description: Send data to multiple output targets from a single job.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Analyze data for a threshold-based alert and archive all events to blob storage
trans-unit.target: e.g. Analyze data for a threshold-based alert and archive all events to blob storage

trans-unit.source: The INTO clause tells Stream Analytics which of the outputs to write the data from this statement.
trans-unit.target: The INTO clause tells Stream Analytics which of the outputs to write the data from this statement.

trans-unit.source: The first query is a pass-through of the data we received to an output that we named ArchiveOutput.
trans-unit.target: The first query is a pass-through of the data we received to an output that we named ArchiveOutput.

trans-unit.source: The second query does some simple aggregation and filtering and sends the results to a downstream alerting system.
trans-unit.target: The second query does some simple aggregation and filtering and sends the results to a downstream alerting system.

trans-unit.source: Note: You can also reuse results of CTEs (i.e. WITH statements) in multiple output statements – this has the added benefit of opening less readers to the input source.
trans-unit.target: Note: You can also reuse results of CTEs (i.e. WITH statements) in multiple output statements – this has the added benefit of opening less readers to the input source.

trans-unit.source: Description: count the number of unique field values that appear in the stream within a time window.
trans-unit.target: Description: count the number of unique field values that appear in the stream within a time window.

trans-unit.source: e.g. How many unique make of cars passed through the toll booth in a 2 second window?
trans-unit.target: e.g. How many unique make of cars passed through the toll booth in a 2 second window?

trans-unit.source: We do an initial aggregation to get unique makes with their count over the window.
trans-unit.target: We do an initial aggregation to get unique makes with their count over the window.

trans-unit.source: We then do an aggregation of how many makes we got – given all unique values in a window get the same timestamp then the second aggregation window needs to be minimal to not aggregate 2 windows from the first step.
trans-unit.target: We then do an aggregation of how many makes we got – given all unique values in a window get the same timestamp then the second aggregation window needs to be minimal to not aggregate 2 windows from the first step.

trans-unit.source: Determine if a value has changed
trans-unit.target: Determine if a value has changed

trans-unit.source: Description: Look at a previous value to determine if it is different than the current value
trans-unit.target: Description: Look at a previous value to determine if it is different than the current value

trans-unit.source: e.g. Is the previous car on the Toll Road the same make as the current car?
trans-unit.target: e.g. Is the previous car on the Toll Road the same make as the current car?

trans-unit.source: Use LAG to peek into the input stream one event back and get the Make value.
trans-unit.target: Use LAG to peek into the input stream one event back and get the Make value.

trans-unit.source: Then compare it to the Make on the current event and output the event if they are different.
trans-unit.target: Then compare it to the Make on the current event and output the event if they are different.

trans-unit.source: Find first event in a window
trans-unit.target: Find first event in a window

trans-unit.source: Description: Find first car in every 10 minute interval?
trans-unit.target: Description: Find first car in every 10 minute interval?

trans-unit.source: Now let’s change the problem and find first car of particular Make in every 10 minute interval.
trans-unit.target: Now let’s change the problem and find first car of particular Make in every 10 minute interval.

trans-unit.source: Find last event in a window
trans-unit.target: Find last event in a window

trans-unit.source: Description: Find last car in every 10 minute interval.
trans-unit.target: Description: Find last car in every 10 minute interval.

trans-unit.source: There are two steps in the query – the first one finds latest timestamp in 10 minute windows.
trans-unit.target: There are two steps in the query – the first one finds latest timestamp in 10 minute windows.

trans-unit.source: The second step joins results of the first query with original stream to find events matching last timestamps in each window.
trans-unit.target: The second step joins results of the first query with original stream to find events matching last timestamps in each window.

trans-unit.source: Description: Check that a stream has no value that matches a certain criteria.
trans-unit.target: Description: Check that a stream has no value that matches a certain criteria.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Have 2 consecutive cars from the same make entered the toll road within 90 seconds?
trans-unit.target: e.g. Have 2 consecutive cars from the same make entered the toll road within 90 seconds?

trans-unit.source: Use LAG to peek into the input stream one event back and get the Make value.
trans-unit.target: Use LAG to peek into the input stream one event back and get the Make value.

trans-unit.source: Then compare it to the Make on the current event and output the event if they are the same and use LAG to get data about the previous car.
trans-unit.target: Then compare it to the Make on the current event and output the event if they are the same and use LAG to get data about the previous car.

trans-unit.source: Description: Find out how long a condition occurred for.
trans-unit.target: Description: Find out how long a condition occurred for.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Suppose that a bug that resulted in all cars having an incorrect (above 20,000 pounds) – we want to compute the duration of the bug.
trans-unit.target: e.g. Suppose that a bug that resulted in all cars having an incorrect (above 20,000 pounds) – we want to compute the duration of the bug.

trans-unit.source: We are looking for 2 good events with a bad event in between and without a good event in between which means the 2 events are the first events before and after at least 1 bad event.
trans-unit.target: We are looking for 2 good events with a bad event in between and without a good event in between which means the 2 events are the first events before and after at least 1 bad event.

trans-unit.source: Getting 2 good events with 1 bad event in the middle is simple using 2 JOINs and validating that we get good -> bad -> good by checking the weight and comparing the time stamps.
trans-unit.target: Getting 2 good events with 1 bad event in the middle is simple using 2 JOINs and validating that we get good -> bad -> good by checking the weight and comparing the time stamps.

trans-unit.source: Using what we learned on “LEFT Outer Join to include NULLs or to do absence of events” we know how to check that no good event has occurred between the 2 good events we picked up.
trans-unit.target: Using what we learned on “LEFT Outer Join to include NULLs or to do absence of events” we know how to check that no good event has occurred between the 2 good events we picked up.

trans-unit.source: Composing those together and we get good -> bad -> good with no other good event in between.
trans-unit.target: Composing those together and we get good -> bad -> good with no other good event in between.

trans-unit.source: We can now compute the duration between the beginning and end good events which gives us the duration of the bug.
trans-unit.target: We can now compute the duration between the beginning and end good events which gives us the duration of the bug.

trans-unit.source: For further assistance, try our <link><linkText>Azure Stream Analytics forum</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For further assistance, try our <link><linkText>Azure Stream Analytics forum</linkText><title></title></link>
